RIVERSIDE Calif PERIOD  A federal judge in Riverside Calif. who last month struck down the RIVERSIDE Calif PERIOD  A federal judge in Riverside Calif. who last month struck down the militarys dont ask dont tell policy imposed an injunction on Tuesday ordering federal officials not to enforce the controversial policy on gays in the military PERIOD

The federal government has  days to appeal but Justice Department attorneys have not said whether they will PERIOD

U.S PERIOD District Court Judge Virginia A PERIOD Phillips wrote that the defendants the United States of America and the Secretary of Defense must immediately suspend and discontinue any investigation or discharge separation or other proceeding that may have been commenced under the Dont Ask Dont Tell Act or pursuant to  U.S.C PERIOD  or its implementing regulations on or prior to the dat e of this Judgment. in September Phillips said the policy banning gays did not preserve military readiness contrary to what many supporters have argued and that evidence shows that the policy in fact had a direct and deleterious effect on the military PERIOD She also found that dont ask dont tell violated the First Amendment PERIOD

Phillips said at the time that she would issue an injunction barring the government from enforcing the policy PERIOD

The case was filed by the Log Cabin Republicans the largest political organization for gays in the GOP in  PERIOD

During the trial Justice Department attorney Paul G PERIOD Freeborne argued that Congress  not a federal court  should have the authority and the responsibility to enact military policy PERIOD The sole evidence presented by the Justice Department was the legislative history of the ban which government lawyers argued showed that the policy was properly adopted by Congress through a deliberative and reasoned political process PERIOD No witnesses were called PERIOD

Conversely attorneys for the Log Cabin Republicans called to the stand several decorated military officers discharged for their sexual orientation including Air Force Maj PERIOD Michael Almy PERIOD Almy who deployed three times to Iraq said his commanding officer attempted to force him to admit he was gay after another service member without permission searched Almys private email and found a message discussing homosexual conduct PERIOD After fighting his dismissal for  months Almy agreed to accept an honorable discharge PERIOD
